string-array.name: families_description
string-array.item: Herbivorous dinosaurs with bodies protected by spikes and hard plates.
Herbivorous dinosaurs with horns and frills on their skulls.
Herbivorous dinosaurs with strong jaws and flattened teeth, often referred to as "duck-billed dinosaurs".
Herbivorous dinosaurs with jaws equipped with teeth and often having horn-like structures or frills.
Flying reptiles with membranous wings connected to their limbs.
Large-bodied dinosaurs with long necks, strong legs, and long tails. They were herbivorous.
Carnivorous dinosaurs with sharp claws, sharp teeth, and usually bipedal movement.
Herbivorous dinosaurs characterized by their long necks, pot-bellied bodies, small heads, and large, curved claws on their hands.

string-array.name: families_period
string-array.item: From the Late Jurassic Period to the Late Cretaceous Period (about 160 million - 66 million years ago).
From the Early Cretaceous Period to the Late Cretaceous Period (about 145 million - 66 million years ago).
From the Early Cretaceous Period to the Late Cretaceous Period (about 145 million - 66 million years ago).
From the Late Triassic Period to the Late Cretaceous Period (about 230 million - 65 million years ago).
From the Late Triassic Period to the Late Cretaceous Period (about 228 million - 66 million years ago).
From the Late Triassic Period to the Late Cretaceous Period (about 230 million - 65 million years ago).
From the Late Triassic Period to the Late Cretaceous Period (about 230 million - 65 million years ago).
From the Late Cretaceous Period (around 145 million - 66 million years ago).

string-array.name: families_physics
string-array.item: Low-slung bodies with hard plates or spiked bones protecting their bodies.
Prominent horns and frills on the skull, as well as large bodies with four legs.
Large bodies with powerful jaws and rows of flattened teeth.
Typically have heavy bodies, short legs, and jaws equipped with teeth for chewing plants.
Light bodies with wide wings, and sometimes horns or crests on the skull.
Large body size, long necks, and small claws. Their vertebral column consists of large vertebrae.
Typically have lightweight bodies, long legs, and strong claws. Some species had feathers.

Long necks, large torsos, and relatively small skulls with toothless beaks. One of their most distinctive features was the large, sickle-shaped claws on their hands, which were likely used for manipulating vegetation.

string-array.name: families_habitat
string-array.item: Typically found in scrub-land or forested areas.
Typically found in lowland or more open areas.
Lived in various habitats including forests, floodplains, and open areas.
Lived in various habitats including forests, floodplains, and open areas.
Typically found in coastal areas and waters, although some species also lived on land.
Typically found in terrestrial environments, often in lowland areas and forests.
Found in various habitats including forests, lowlands, and desert areas.
Inhabited in forested environments, where they could feed on a variety of plant material, including leaves, fruits, and possibly even small branches.

string-array.name: families_behaviour
string-array.item: Tended to have defensive behaviors, using their shields and natural weapons to protect themselves from predators.
May have lived in herds to defend territory or find food.
Could have lived in herds for defense or foraging purposes.
Could live in groups or pairs depending on the species.
Many species are believed to be aerial predators, hunting over water or gliding through the air to catch prey.
Sauropods are believed to have migrated in large groups to find food.
May have hunted in groups or individually, depending on the species.

Primarily herbivorous, using their specialized claws to reach and strip vegetation. Some researchers suggest that they may have also been facultative omnivores, occasionally consuming small animals or insects.

string-array.name: families_classification
string-array.item: Ankylosauria is an order within the subclass Dinosauria.
Ceratopsia is an order within the subclass Dinosauria.
Hadrosauridae is a family within the order Ornithischia.
Ornithischia is an order within the subclass Dinosauria.
Pterosauria is a sister group to dinosaurs, included in the class Archosauria.
Classified as a group within the order Saurischia.
Theropoda is an order within the subclass Dinosauria.

Therizinosauria is an order within the subclass Dinosauria. They were initially classified as theropods due to their similarities in skeletal features, but further study revealed their unique adaptations for herbivory.

string-array.name: dinosaur_description
string-array.item: Ankylosaurus was a heavily armored herbivorous dinosaur known for its thick, bony plates along its back and a club-like tail.
Stegosaurus was a herbivorous dinosaur known for its distinctive double row of large, bony plates along its back and pairs of spikes on its tail.
Triceratops was a large herbivorous dinosaur known for its three facial horns and bony frill at the back of its skull.
Styracosaurus was a herbivorous dinosaur known for its distinctive frill of spikes around its neck and a single long nasal horn.
Edmontosaurus was a large herbivorous dinosaur known for its duck-billed appearance and toothless beak.
Corythosaurus was a herbivorous dinosaur known for its distinctive helmet-like crest on top of its skull.
Parasaurolophus was a herbivorous dinosaur known for its elaborate cranial crest, which extended backward from its skull.
Iguanodon was a herbivorous dinosaur known for its thumb spike and ability to switch between bipedal and quadrupedal locomotion.
Pteranodon was a large flying reptile known for its distinctive crest on the back of its head and its long, toothless beak.
Quetzalcoatlus was one of the largest flying reptiles known to have existed, with a wingspan rivaling that of a small airplane.
Argentinosaurus was a massive herbivorous dinosaur, one of the largest terrestrial animals to have ever lived.
Brachiosaurus was a large herbivorous dinosaur known for its long neck, small head, and front legs longer than its hind legs.
Carnotaurus was a medium-sized predatory dinosaur known for its distinctive horns above the eyes and deep skull.
Tyrannosaurus rex, often referred to as T. rex, was a large predatory dinosaur known for its massive skull, powerful jaws, and serrated teeth.
Therizinosaurus was a large herbivorous dinosaur with long claws on its hands, thought to have been used for stripping vegetation.
Nothronychus was a therizinosaurid dinosaur known for its large size and distinctive sickle-shaped claws on its hands.

string-array.name: dinosaur_characteristic
string-array.item: It had a low-slung body covered in bony plates called osteoderms and a tail ending in a large bony club, which it likely used for defense against predators.
It had a small head, a long neck, a heavy, armored body, and short legs. The most recognizable feature is the array of large, kite-shaped plates along its back.
It had a bulky body, a large skull with a parrot-like beak, and a bony frill extending from the back of its head.
It had a bulky body, a large skull with a beak, and a frill adorned with several long spikes projecting outward.
It had a bulky body, a long tail, and a broad, flat head with a toothless beak resembling that of a duck.
It had a long, slender body, a long tail, and a skull with a hollow, helmet-like crest that extended backward from its skull.
It had a long, tubular crest that extended from its skull, likely used for vocalization and display purposes.
It had a bulky body, a long tail, and a thumb spike that may have been used for defense or foraging.
It had a long, slender body, large wings supported by a single elongated finger, and a long, toothless beak adapted for catching fish.
It had a long, slender body, large wings supported by an elongated fourth finger, and a long, toothless beak adapted for catching prey.
It had a long neck, a small head, a bulky body, and a long tail. Despite its size, its limbs were relatively slender.
It had a tall, giraffe-like build, with its front legs significantly longer than its hind legs, giving it a sloping posture.
It had a sleek, muscular body with short, stubby arms, a thick neck, and powerful jaws lined with sharp teeth.
It had a robust body, long hind limbs for fast running, and tiny forelimbs with two-fingered hands.
It had a bulky body, a long neck, and exceptionally long, scythe-like claws on its hands, which were among the longest claws of any known dinosaur.
It had a large, bulky body, a long neck, and large, sickle-shaped claws on its hands, suggesting it was an herbivore.

string-array.name: dinosaur_group
string-array.item: Ankylosaurus belongs to the family Ankylosauridae within the order Ornithischia.
Stegosaurus belongs to the family Stegosauridae within the order Ornithischia.
Triceratops belongs to the family Ceratopsidae within the order Ornithischia.
Styracosaurus belongs to the family Ceratopsidae within the order Ornithischia.
Edmontosaurus belongs to the family Hadrosauridae within the order Ornithischia.
Corythosaurus belongs to the family Hadrosauridae within the order Ornithischia.
Parasaurolophus belongs to the family Hadrosauridae within the order Ornithischia.
Iguanodon belongs to the family Iguanodontidae within the order Ornithischia.
Pteranodon belongs to the order Pterosauria.
Quetzalcoatlus belongs to the order Pterosauria.
Argentinosaurus belongs to the family Titanosauridae within the order Sauropoda.
Brachiosaurus belongs to the family Brachiosauridae within the order Sauropoda.
Carnotaurus belongs to the family Abelisauridae within the order Theropoda.
Tyrannosaurus belongs to the family Tyrannosauridae within the order Theropoda.
Therizinosaurus belongs to the family Therizinosauridae within the order Theropoda.
Nothronychus belongs to the family Therizinosauridae within the order Theropoda.

string-array.name: dinosaur_habitat
string-array.item: Ankylosaurus inhabited wooded and open habitats during the Late Cretaceous period.
Stegosaurus lived in woodlands and semi-arid environments during the Late Jurassic period.
Triceratops inhabited woodlands and plains during the Late Cretaceous period.
Styracosaurus inhabited woodlands and plains during the Late Cretaceous period.
Edmontosaurus inhabited woodlands and floodplains during the Late Cretaceous period.
Corythosaurus inhabited woodlands and floodplains during the Late Cretaceous period.
Parasaurolophus inhabited woodlands and floodplains during the Late Cretaceous period.
Iguanodon inhabited woodlands and floodplains during the Early Cretaceous period.
Pteranodon inhabited coastal regions and marine environments during the Late Cretaceous period.
Quetzalcoatlus inhabited coastal regions and inland environments during the Late Cretaceous period.
Argentinosaurus inhabited forested floodplains and river valleys during the Late Cretaceous period.
Brachiosaurus inhabited forested floodplains and upland environments during the Late Jurassic period.
Carnotaurus inhabited open woodlands and plains during the Late Cretaceous period.
Tyrannosaurus inhabited various environments, including forests, plains, and coastal regions, during the Late Cretaceous period.
Therizinosaurus likely inhabited forested environments during the Late Cretaceous period.
Nothronychus likely inhabited forested environments during the Early Cretaceous period.

string-array.name: dinosaur_food
string-array.item: As an herbivore, Ankylosaurus primarily fed on low-lying vegetation, such as ferns and cycads.
It likely fed on low-lying vegetation, such as ferns, mosses, and cycads.
As an herbivore, it likely fed on low-lying vegetation, using its tough beak and powerful jaws to strip leaves and branches.
As an herbivore, it likely fed on low-lying vegetation, using its tough beak and powerful jaws to strip leaves and branches.
As an herbivore, it likely fed on low-lying vegetation, using its beak and rows of teeth to grind plant material.
As an herbivore, it likely fed on low-lying vegetation, using its beak and rows of teeth to grind plant material.
As an herbivore, it likely fed on low-lying vegetation, using its beak and rows of teeth to grind plant material.
As an herbivore, it likely fed on low-lying vegetation, using its beak and teeth to strip leaves and branches.
As a piscivore, it primarily fed on fish, using its sharp beak to catch prey while in flight.
As a carnivore, it likely preyed on small animals, including fish, reptiles, and possibly even small dinosaurs.
As a herbivore, it likely fed on vast quantities of low-lying vegetation, such as ferns, horsetails, and conifers.
As a herbivore, it likely fed on tall vegetation, such as conifers and ferns, using its long neck to reach high branches.
As a carnivore, it likely hunted small to medium-sized prey, using its speed and agility to catch its victims.
As a carnivore, it was a formidable apex predator, preying on a variety of dinosaurs, including herbivores like Triceratops.
As an herbivore, it likely fed on vegetation, using its long claws to reach and strip leaves from branches.
As an herbivore, it likely fed on vegetation, using its claws to reach and strip leaves from branches.

string-array.name: dinosaur_weakness
string-array.item: Despite its heavy armor, Ankylosaurus may have been vulnerable to attacks from agile and fast predators due to its relatively slow speed.
Despite its armor and spiked tail, Stegosaurus may have been susceptible to attacks from large predators due to its relatively small size and slow speed.
Despite its formidable horns and frill, Triceratops may have been vulnerable to attacks from large predators due to its relatively slow speed and limited agility.
Despite its formidable frill and horn, Styracosaurus may have been vulnerable to attacks from large predators due to its relatively slow speed and limited agility.
Despite its size, Edmontosaurus may have been vulnerable to attacks from large predators due to its relatively slow speed and limited agility.
Despite its size, Corythosaurus may have been vulnerable to attacks from large predators due to its relatively slow speed and limited agility.
Despite its size, Parasaurolophus may have been vulnerable to attacks from large predators due to its relatively slow speed and limited agility.
Despite its size, Iguanodon may have been vulnerable to attacks from large predators due to its relatively slow speed and limited agility.
Despite its aerial prowess, Pteranodon may have been vulnerable to attacks from large marine predators while hunting for fish.
Despite its immense size, Quetzalcoatlus may have been vulnerable to attacks from large predators while on the ground or during takeoff and landing.
Despite its immense size, Argentinosaurus may have been vulnerable to attacks from large predators due to its relatively slow speed and limited agility.
Despite its size, Brachiosaurus may have been susceptible to attacks from large predators due to its relatively slow speed and limited agility.
Despite its speed and agility, Carnotaurus may have been relatively fragile compared to larger predators, relying more on ambush tactics than direct confrontation.
Despite its size and power, Tyrannosaurus may have had limited agility and endurance, potentially making it vulnerable during prolonged chases.
Despite its formidable claws, Therizinosaurus may have been relatively slow-moving and may have lacked strong defensive capabilities against large predators.
Despite its size and claws, Nothronychus may have been relatively slow-moving and may have lacked strong defensive capabilities against large predators.
